article.headline: LSU 71, Mississippi St. 57
article.story: STARKVILLE, Miss. (AP) -- LSU hasn't started this strongly in SEC play since the Dale Brown era. The Tigers beat Mississippi State 71-57 on Wednesday night behind 17 points from Glen Davis, and have won their first three Southeastern Conference games for the first time since Brown's 1994-95 team opened 4-0 in league play. Now, with victories at Arkansas and Mississippi State sandwiching a home win over Tennessee, LSU coach John Brady hopes to avoid the finish that wrecked his predecessor's once-promising season 11 years ago -- when the Tigers lost 11 of their last 13 games and finished with a losing record. "To win three SEC games, two on the road, having gone to Arkansas and beating a good Arkansas team ... Being 3-0 is a good place to be," coach John Brady said. Mississippi State "is tough to beat here, regardless of how their team is." Darrel Mitchell added 15 points and freshman Tyrus Thomas added 14 points and 10 rebounds for the Tigers (11-5, 3-0 Southeastern Conference), who won their third straight and fourth in five games. Davis, who entered as the SEC's leading scorer with an 18-point average, had 11 in the first half for LSU, which trailed only in the game's opening moments in winning its third straight against the Bulldogs and prompting Mississippi State coach Rick Stansbury to call the Tigers one of the best teams he's seen. "Not in the West (Division), in the SEC, absolutely," Stansbury said. "If you look back at their (five) losses, that's the only reason they're not a Top 10 team." The Tigers, the only team to win at No. 12 West Virginia, have lost five games by a total 11 points. "I think we can be pretty good, and we have proven that we can play with the best teams in the country," Brady said. Mississippi State twice got as close as seven in the second half, but both times the Tigers responded by quickly restoring their double-figure lead. Charles Rhodes pulled the Bulldogs to 54-47 with just less than 9 minutes to play, but Thomas countered by dunking over two Mississippi State players and Darnell Lazare hit two free throws to make it an 11-point game. Mississippi State didn't get closer than eight the rest of the way. "We were a little bit better around the goal, and that was the difference," Brady said. Jamont Gordon had 17 points and 13 rebounds for Mississippi State (11-6, 1-3), which has lost three straight games for the first time since 2002-03. Jamall Edmondson added 15 points off the bench and Rhodes added 14 points for the Bulldogs. LSU, which entered as the SEC's best rebounding team with nearly 45 per game, was outrebounded 40-33. "That's the best frontcourt in America," Stansbury said. "There aren't none better than those guys combined." Garrett Temple added 10 points for the Tigers. "If we can get a little bit of guard play, and have someone like Garrett Temple step up, our team has proven that it can be pretty good," Brady said. LSU held Mississippi State to one field goal during a 6-minute stretch in which it broke a 15-all tie with a 13-2 run, which pushed the lead to 28-17. The Tigers led by as many as 13 in the first half and were up 41-30 at halftime. The dismissals of forwards Walter Sharpe and Jerrell Houston earlier this week left Mississippi State with a thin bench. Edmondson, who has been nursing an injured groin, was the only nonstarter to score for the Bulldogs.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
